name: National Association of Muslim Charitable Clinics
theoryOfChange: By uniting, supporting, and training Muslim charitable clinics, the association enhances their capability to provide high-quality care and expand services to underserved populations.
zakatClaimEvidence: No explicit mention of zakat donations found for the National Association of Muslim Charitable Clinics in the provided search results. The search results describe NAMCC as a non-profit, 501(c)(3) organization that unites healthcare organizations and clinics, and mentions fundraising sources and grant opportunities, but does not specifically state that they accept zakat. (Source: https://naomcc.org/Donations)

all_citations.claim: The organization is identified as a network for healthcare organizations with limited financial metadata available.
Financial data including revenue and program expenses are not currently available in public tax filings.
The organization provides options for general donations and charitable giving.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization receives a lower overall score due to significant gaps in public financial data and a lack of verified impact metrics, resulting in a low data confidence rating.

Lack of transparent financial metrics and independent third-party evaluations

dimension_explanations.alignment: Alignment is considered medium-low as the organization addresses the urgent cause of global health, yet it lacks the specific transparency and track record typically sought by Muslim donors for high-fit alignment [1][3].
dimension_explanations.impact: The impact score is low because there is limited evidence regarding the cost per beneficiary or the direct effectiveness of its capacity-building programs [1][2]. While the organization aims to support member clinics, the lack of reported program expenses makes it difficult to verify its operational efficiency [2].

baseline_narrative.headline: The National Association of Muslim Charitable Clinics serves as a unifying network for healthcare organizations to enhance community wellness through collaborative support.
strengths: Facilitates collaboration between diverse healthcare organizations
Provides a centralized platform for member organization support
Offers clear pathways for general charitable giving (sadaqah)
baseline_narrative.summary: The National Association of Muslim Charitable Clinics (NAOMCC) focuses on uniting healthcare organizations to improve service delivery and provide essential support for its member clinics [1]. The organization facilitates collective action among charitable medical providers and offers various donation options for those wishing to contribute sadaqah to their mission [3].

case_against.summary: The primary concerns involve <cite id="15">low data confidence</cite> and a <cite id="16">critically small board</cite> which may limit long-term sustainability.

confidence.notes: Data is extremely limited due to the organization's emerging status.

alignment.explanation: Alignment is 23/50, reflecting a <cite id="19">high cause urgency in global health</cite> but a <cite id="20">low Muslim donor fit</cite> due to the lack of specific religious giving frameworks beyond general sadaqah.
alignment.improvement: Alignment could be improved by <cite id="21">clearly stating the Islamic principles</cite> guiding its healthcare advocacy to better resonate with faith-motivated donors.

credibility.explanation: Credibility is grounded in meeting <cite id="11">BBB accountability standards</cite>, though it is limited by <cite id="15">low data quality (0.33)</cite> and a <cite id="16">small board of only 2 members</cite>.
credibility.improvement: To strengthen credibility, the organization should <cite id="16">expand its board size</cite> beyond the current two members to ensure more diverse oversight.

impact.explanation: Impact is currently rated at 14/50 because the <cite id="17">delivery model focuses on capacity building</cite> rather than direct patient care, and <cite id="14">program expense ratios are currently unknown</cite>.
impact.improvement: The organization should <cite id="18">publish beneficiary counts consistently</cite> so that its cost-effectiveness can be properly assessed by donors.

rich_narrative.headline: The National Association of Muslim Charitable Clinics serves as a unifying network for healthcare organizations to enhance community wellness through collaborative support.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who want to support the structural development of Muslim-run healthcare clinics in the US through general charitable giving.
donor_motivations: Value the professionalization of Muslim charitable clinics
Prefer supporting infrastructure and advocacy over direct aid
Want to contribute to the long-term sustainability of community health
giving_considerations: Donations are for sadaqah and do not fulfill zakat obligations
The organization is in a growth phase with limited historical data
Impact is indirect through member clinic support
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking to fulfill zakat obligations or those requiring high-transparency financial ratios and direct patient impact metrics.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade C reflects an <cite id="22">emerging organization baseline</cite> where outcomes are currently unverified.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: By strengthening member clinics through training and advocacy, the organization indirectly improves health outcomes for underserved communities.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence is crucial for capacity builders to prove that their training actually results in better clinic performance.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: As a developing network, there is significant room to absorb funding to expand advocacy and member services.

strengths.detail: The organization successfully <cite id="1">facilitates collaboration between diverse healthcare organizations</cite> to improve community wellness.
Provides a <cite id="6">centralized platform</cite> that offers <cite id="4">education, training, and resource pooling</cite> for charitable clinics.
The organization <cite id="11">meets all 20 BBB Wise Giving Alliance Standards</cite> for Charity Accountability, including having a <cite id="12">conflict of interest policy</cite>.

strengths_deep_dive: The NAOMCC's primary strength lies in its role as a backbone organization for the Muslim charitable clinic sector. By focusing on <cite id="5">advocacy efforts</cite> and <cite id="3">support for member organizations</cite>, it creates a multiplier effect where improvements in the association benefit multiple frontline clinics. Its commitment to accountability is evidenced by its <cite id="11">20/20 rating from the BBB Wise Giving Alliance</cite>, which confirms the presence of <cite id="13">audited financial statements</cite> and sound board oversight.
rich_narrative.summary: The National Association of Muslim Charitable Clinics (NAOMCC) operates as a <cite id="1">unifying network for healthcare organizations</cite> dedicated to enhancing community wellness through collaborative support. As a capacity-building entity, the organization focuses on <cite id="2">uniting healthcare organizations</cite> to streamline service delivery and provide <cite id="3">support for member organizations</cite> across the United States. While the organization is in a developing stage, its core mission involves <cite id="4">education and training</cite> alongside <cite id="5">advocacy efforts</cite> to strengthen the infrastructure of charitable medical providers. The NAOMCC serves as a <cite id="6">centralized platform for member organization support</cite>, facilitating resource pooling and collective action to address health disparities. Currently, the organization provides <cite id="7">clear pathways for general charitable giving</cite>, specifically focusing on <cite id="8">sadaqah contributions</cite> to fund its operations. Despite its specialized niche, the organization maintains a <cite id="9">geographic coverage across the USA</cite>, aiming to bridge gaps in the global health cause area through domestic clinic support. However, as an emerging institution, it currently operates with <cite id="10">limited public disclosure of program outcomes</cite> and lacks the historical financial depth of larger peers.
